Posts.Content: Hi I had an immediate recon last October (LD flap with implant) and the result is great. Stil waiting for nipple recon and may have a slight uplift on other side. I have a scar that runs halfway along my back but not visible under my bra strap. I am able to do everything that I could do before my surgery, lifting, using the rowing machine at the gym etc. Your consultant should be able to guide you as to what surgery would be best for you. Ask to see some pictures of the surgeons work. My breastcare nurse showed me pictures of my surgeons previous operations. It may be that you will have a different surgeon depending on what procedure you choose so ask who will be carrying out your op. Hope all goes well with your surgery Kirstie
Posts.Title: reconstruction diep, tram or ld

Posts.Content: Hi Emma I had immediate LD reconstruction last October and can honestly say that there is no difference in the things I do now than the things I did before. I go regularly to the gym and am back to my pre-op routine including rowing, crosstraining and weights. My job also involves an element of heavy lifting at times and I have no trouble with this. Definitley don't feel lop sided, the only thing is sometimes a slight tightness on the recon side but moving and exercising soon eases that. Really pleased with the shape, seeing my surgeon next month about nipple recon and an uplift to even up the other side (just me being fussy though!). The scar along my back is easily covered by bra or bikini strap and the scar at the front is rapidly fading and hopefully once I have had the nipple tatooing will be even less noticable. Good luck in making your decision Kirstie
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Firstly well done on your Race for Life acheivement, what a fantastic sum you raised. So sorry you are having to go through this, the only advice I can give is take this one step at a time, your feelings at tne moment are completley normal and all of us here have been through this stage. Once your treatment starts hopefully you will feel a little more in control but be prepared for some days to be better than others this process is as others on here will tell you is a real rollercoaster ride of emotions! Look after yourself and call your BC nurse if you have any concerns about how you are feeling. There is a younger womens forum on here and also many hospital support units have younger women support groups, if you feel these may help ask your nurse if she has any details. Thinking of you Kirstie
Posts.Title: 28 & newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Wow Pat you are doing amazingly well to get back to work so quickly. I had the same surgery last October (but no lymph node removal) and I was told not to drive for 6 weeks. I would say that it took me at least a couple of months before I even started to feel that I could move properly. Admittedly I started my chemo 4 weeks after my surgery so this may have slowed down my progress. I still get odd twinges and weird sensations although I would say that it is not really painful anymore. My back gets a bit stiff sometimes and I find it a little uncomfortable at times to lay on the side of my surgery. Most of the time I am not aware of it now, I have no restrictions in my movement and would say I am pretty much back to pre-op strength. I think you will find that surgery recovery wise you will feel better and better each week that passes. Hope the rest of your treatment goes well. Look after yourself. Kirstie x
Posts.Title: How long of a recovery time from op ????

Posts.Content: Hi Pat I found the exercises really helped so made sure I did them religiously! I had 2 wigs one similar to my normal hair, shoulder length bob and one longer one but in the end I only wore them a couple of times, had my treatment through the winter so just wore hats, got lots to match my outfits! I finished my chemo in February and hair started to grow back within a couple of weeks but grew much quicker around the sides than on the top so looked a bit odd for a while. I still wear a hat to work but after a week off next week will probably brave it with no hat when I go back. Glad being able to work is helping, I think that just trying to keep a sense of normality where you can helps you to stop going mad. Thanks for your friend request, will message you later in week. Happy to share any of my experiences if it helps. Kirstie x

Posts.Content: Link below may help. I think it depends on whether you have an H2 or an H3 certificate   http://www.nhs.uk/NHSEngland/Healthcosts/Pages/Dentalcosts.aspx Summary below You do not have to pay for NHS dental treatment if, when the treatment starts, you are: aged under 18 under 19 and receiving full-time education pregnant or have had a baby in the previous 12 months staying in an NHS hospital and your treatment is carried out by the hospital dentist an NHS hospital dental service outpatient (however, you may have to pay for your dentures or bridges). You also do not have to pay if, when the treatment starts, you are receiving: Income Support Income-related Employment and Support Allowance Income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance Pension Credit guarantee credit or you are named on a valid NHS tax credit exemption certificate or you are entitled to an NHS tax credit exemption certificate you are named on a valid HC2 certificate Find out more about the NHS Low Income Scheme (LIS).     Partial help If your name is on a valid HC3 certificate, you may not have to pay for all your treatment. Checks are made on free and reduced cost treatment claims. If you say you have the right to free treatment when you do not, you may incur a penalty charge.  Note You will not be exempt from paying because you receive: Incapacity Benefit, contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance, contribution-based Jobseeker’s Allowance, Disability Living Allowance, Council Tax Benefit, Housing Benefit or Pension Credit savings credit, when paid on their own. Medical conditions do not exempt patients from payment for dental treatment. You will be asked to show your dentist written proof that you do not have to pay for all or part of your NHS treatment. You will also be asked to sign a form to confirm that you do not have to pay.
Posts.Title: Medical Exemption Certificate

Posts.Content: Hi I was a regular gym user and runner before my surgery and chemo - FEC-T (Sept 2011 -Feb 2012) and was determined that I would be able to carry on going to the gym throughout my treatment. However I ended up putting my membership on hold shortly after my first FEC. I didn't have awful side effects with the FEC but just did not have the energy to go to the gym, the docetaxel made me more unwell and I barely got out of bed let alone exercised! I started going back to the gym in May and still find it quite tiring but it is helping me feel more normal again. I think whilst you are undergoing treatment I would stick to exercise you can do as and when you feel up to it, walks (in the Great British sunshine?!) are great and as others have said much less risk of picking up infections. Good luck with your treatment, take care Kirstie
Posts.Title: GYM

Posts.Content: Hi I have been taking tamoxifen since March and fortunately very few side effects. I was originally taking it first thing in the morning but was suffering with hot flushes (and strangely really hot hands and feet!) at night that meant I was awake at least 4 or 5 times a night trying to cool down so consequently very tired. I recently changed to taking my tablet in the evening and it has made a huge difference, I only wake up briefly once or twice, turn my pillow over and then straight back to sleep. i also have a chillow which is great and was also advised to tale sage tablets, (got mine from Holland and Barrett) Good luck Kirstie
Posts.Title: has anyone had any possive experiences with Tamoxifen????? Am due...

Posts.Content: Hi Carol I had immediate recon last October and was told to buy sports bra and bra expanders (can get them from Marks or Debenhams). BC nurses came to check that they fitted properly a few days after surgery. I guess advice may vary according to where you are having your treatment. I had no problems with the sports bra, wore them all the time for 4-5 months post surgery. Good luck, hope surgery goes well Kirstie

Posts.Content: Hi Jules My Mx and recon was also 8 months ago today! I have also had the sorts of pains you are describing, I saw my surgeon yesterday and he said it can take 12 months for everything to settle down and that it is most likely nerve pain where the nerves are still trying to make connections. Kirstie x
Posts.Title: phantom or coincidental pain

Posts.Content: Hello Glad you are feeling a bit better today. Tramadol can do that to you, it completley knocks me out, took it in hospital after my MX just to get a decent nights sleep! Hope you continue to feel better, take care. Kirstie x
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi all I was also diagnosed in September aged 41. I had lumpectomy (no clear margins)  followed by mastectomy and reconstruction. Finished my chemo in February and did not have to have radiotherapy so can not comment on that side of things. With regards to Tamoxifen I am now in my 3rd month of taking this and like Senga my only slight side effect is mild hot flushes.Senga I know what you mean about it being easier when there is no need for headgear, I have to sometimes resist the temptation to whip my hat of whilst sat at my desk now I am back at work! Don't want to freak out my colleagues! Hopefully only another couple of weeks of hat wearing for me - just need some slow growing patches of hair to catch up with the rest so that I look less like a zombie and more like somebody with a funky (if very short ) hair cut Good luck to you all and hope all your remaining treatments go well   Kirstie x
Posts.Title: Radio Therapy and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Karen I had LD flap reconstruction in Oct 2011 (at the RD &E) Exeter. I have had some evening up surgery on my good side and am awaiting a nipple reconstruction. I can honestly say that it has only been the last 3 or 4 months that  I have finally got used to it, I do still miss my old boob but I am truly glad I was able to have immediate recon and it did take a good 12 months before everything had really settled down and I was able to feel properly comfortable with it. Give yourself time to grieve and recover - aside from the shock of a BC diagnosis you have been through a massive surgical procedure and that takes time to get over on it's own. I know it's cliche to say that time is a great healer but in my case I have found this to be both physically and emotionally true. Please get in touch if you want to chat further. Take care Kirstie
Posts.Title: Recon completed so why do I feel so miserable?

Posts.Content: Hi I had ld flap recon last October and I am now back to doing all the 'sporty' stuff I did before. This is mainly gym based but can honestly say that I have no trouble with rowing, cross training or any of the other kit in the gym. I also run and do various classes at the gym. If any thing I find exercise really helps with the slight tightness across my back. Good luck with your decision and any other treatment you have Kirstie
Posts.Title: Advice on reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi I think it is fairly 'normal' for your neutrophyll  count to be so low mid chemo cycle and just becomes a problem if you get an infection. I was got an infection a week or so after my 4th chemo and spent a week in hospital on IV antibiotics as I was neutropenic when I went in however by the end of my stay in hospital my bloods had come back up dramatically and I had my 5th  chemo as normal and on schedule a week later. My chemo nurse told me that even a couple of days can make a big difference to your neutrophyll count so try not to worry your pre chemo bloods will probably be fine.  Fingers crossed for you Kirstie
